Abstract

Problem description

A power network (nodes, branches) is regulated by flow equations based on the First and Second Kirchhoff Laws.

LAW 1: the net flow in a node of the network is zero: âˆ‘jFiâ€‹j+âˆ‘jFjâ€‹i=0subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ¹ğ‘—ğ‘–0\sum_{j}F_{ij}+\sum_{j}F_{ji}=0. The network topology is a graph that may be described by a branch-node incidence matrix Tğ‘‡T (composed of elements with values -1, 1 or 0 only). Nodal injections are described by a vector Lğ¿L. The First Law may be translated into the matrix equation

Tâ€‹F=L.ğ‘‡ğ¹ğ¿T\,F=L\ .

LAW 2: the flow in a branch is proportional to the difference in potential P between its extreme nodes: Fiâ€‹j=biâ€‹jâ€‹(Piâˆ’Pj)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘—F_{ij}=b_{ij}(P_{i}-P_{j}). This may be globally translated into a matrix equation where BğµB is a diagonal matrix:

F=Bâ€‹Ttâ€‹Pğ¹ğµsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘ƒF=B\,T^{t}\,P

The combination of the two Laws produces a well-known circuit equation

Tâ€‹Bâ€‹Ttâ€‹P=LorYâ€‹P=Lformulae-sequenceğ‘‡ğµsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘ƒğ¿orğ‘Œğ‘ƒğ¿T\,B\,T^{t}\,P=L\ \ \mathrm{or}\ \ Y\,P=L

where Yğ‘ŒY is sometimes called a nodal-admittance matrix and Pğ‘ƒP is a vector of nodal potentials.

Question 1

Admit that in a network with nğ‘›n nodes and mğ‘šm branches, one has available kğ‘˜k measurements, with k>nğ‘˜ğ‘›k>n. These measurements may by on a mix of injections Lğ¿L, nodal potentials Pğ‘ƒP and branch flows BğµB.

Admit that these measurements are contaminated with noise. Therefore, the measurements do not form a set compatible with the circuit equation or the Kirchhoff Laws.

Admit that this noise is Gaussian, and independent for each measurement. Admit that the variance is any case is small.

One wishes therefore to find a set of Potentials P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P} that would minimize some reasonable definition of an error between the measurement vector and the vector of values (Fğ¹F, Lğ¿L or Pğ‘ƒP) that is compatible with the circuit equations.

Question 2

Admit that some of the measurement errors are gross errors (much larger than the errors admitted previously), and that it is unknown where such gross errors occur. These may severely contaminate the estimation of P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P}.

Discover which measurements contain gross errors (instead of small errors) and achieve an estimation of P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P} ignoring these gross errors.

Question 3

Admit now that there are switches scattered in the network branches. They can assume a state of open (S=0ğ‘†0S=0) or closed (S=1ğ‘†1S=1). An open switch interrupts the branch flow and eliminates this branch from the network (namely, from matrix Tğ‘‡T).

Admit that there are measuring devices that report each switch status.

Assume that, beside the kğ‘˜k measurements of (Fğ¹F, Lğ¿L or Pğ‘ƒP), some switch status signals are missing so, the network topology becomes unknown.

The challenge is double: to guess correctly the network topology and thus to estimate P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P}.

Also we consider 2 distinct types of networks: DC networks and the DC approximation to AC networks. We do not explicitly work on fully AC networks as the analysis requires a much longer computational time.

3.1.1 DC networks

This is the simpler type of network employed for a preliminary testing of the techniques and methods of network analysis. Only the branches resistance is considered such that Xiâ€‹j=0subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘—0X_{ij}=0 and all quantities are real. Also the admittances to Earth at each node are considered null such that the matrix Yğ‘ŒY is real and symmetric and the lawÂ (3.4) is explicitly given by

Li=âˆ‘kâ‰ isiâ€‹kRiâ€‹kâ€‹(Piâˆ’Pk)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜L_{i}=\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{s_{ik}}{R_{ik}}\left(P_{i}-P_{k}\right) (3.6)

3.1.2 DC approximation to AC networks

This approximation is commonly employed in the analysis of AC power networks. It relies in the fact that for AC power lines the impedance is much bigger than the resistance, the Earth admittances are negligible, the absolute values of the potentials |Pi|subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–|P_{i}| are approximately constant at all nodes and the potential phases Ï•Psubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒ\phi_{P} are small. Hence assuming the following simplifications

  • Xiâ€‹kâ‰«Riâ€‹kmuch-greater-thansubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘˜X_{ik}\gg R_{ik}, for all branches iâ€‹kğ‘–ğ‘˜ik;

  • yiâ‰ˆ0subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–0y_{i}\approx 0, for all nodes iğ‘–i;

  • |Pi|â‰ˆ1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1|P_{i}|\approx 1, for all nodes iğ‘–i (in values per unit);

  • cosâ¡Ï•P,iâ‰ˆ1subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒğ‘–1\cos\phi_{P,i}\approx 1, for all nodes iğ‘–i;

  • sinâ¡Ï•P,iâ‰ˆÏ•P,isubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒğ‘–\sin\phi_{P,i}\approx\phi_{P,i}, for all nodes iğ‘–i,

and decomposing the lawÂ (3.4) into real and imaginary parts we obtain that

LR,i=âˆ‘kâ‰ isiâ€‹kXiâ€‹k(Ï•P,iâˆ’Ï•P,k),LI,iâ‰ˆ0.L_{R,i}=\sum_{k\neq i}\frac{s_{ik}}{X_{ik}}\left(\phi_{P,i}-\phi_{P,k}\right)\ \ ,\ \ L_{I,i}\approx 0\ . (3.7)

3.1.3 AC networks

When higher accuracy measurements are available and it is intended to estimate the potentials Pğ‘ƒP and injections Lğ¿L with an higher accuracy the exact equations can be considered. In such case it can be considered a Cartesian decomposition into the real and imaginary components of lawÂ (3.4)

LR,i=âˆ‘k=1N(YR,iâ€‹kâ€‹PR,kâˆ’YI,iâ€‹kâ€‹PI,k),LI,i=âˆ‘k=1N(YI,iâ€‹kâ€‹PR,k+YR,iâ€‹kâ€‹PI,k),subscriptğ¿ğ‘…ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘…ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ¿ğ¼ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘…ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ¼ğ‘˜\begin{array}[]{rcl}\displaystyle L_{R,i}&=&\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}\left(Y_{R,ik}P_{R,k}-Y_{I,ik}P_{I,k}\right)\ ,\\ \displaystyle L_{I,i}&=&\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}\left(Y_{I,ik}P_{R,k}+Y_{R,ik}P_{I,k}\right)\ ,\end{array} (3.8)

where YR,iâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘Œğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘˜Y_{R,ik} and YI,iâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘Œğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘˜Y_{I,ik} stand for the real and imaginary components of the complex matrix entries Yiâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘—Y_{ij}.

In the analysis of power networks it is often considered the Euler form such that the several quantities are represented by their absolute value and phase. Considering a decomposition of the complex matrix entries Yiâ€‹k=|Yiâ€‹k|â€‹(cosâ¡Ï•Y,iâ€‹k+jâ€‹sinâ¡Ï•Y,iâ€‹k)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜Y_{ik}=|Y_{ik}|(\cos\phi_{Y,ik}+j\sin\phi_{Y,ik}) and the decompositionÂ (3.5) for the Pğ‘ƒPâ€™s and Lğ¿Lâ€™s, the lawÂ (3.4) is expressed as

|Li|=âˆ‘k=1N|Yiâ€‹k|â€‹|Pk|â€‹cosâ¡(Ï•Y,iâ€‹k+Ï•P,k)cosâ¡(Ï•L,i),tanâ¡(Ï•L,i)=âˆ‘k=1Ntanâ¡(Ï•Y,iâ€‹k+Ï•P,k).subscriptğ¿ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ¿ğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ¿ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ƒğ‘˜\begin{array}[]{rcl}\displaystyle|L_{i}|&=&\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}|Y_{ik}||P_{k}|\frac{\cos\left(\phi_{Y,ik}+\phi_{P,k}\right)}{\cos(\phi_{L,i})}\ ,\\ \displaystyle\tan(\phi_{L,i})&=&\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{N}\tan(\phi_{Y,ik}+\phi_{P,k})\ .\end{array} (3.9)

The Cartesian decompositionÂ (3.8) has the advantage of representing the lawÂ (3.4) by a linear expression as opposed to the Euler formÂ (3.9). Hence, as long as non-linear effects on networks are negligible, the Cartesian decomposition simplifies the technical formulation and analysis of the network equations, however the estimative errors is lower when considering the Euler decomposition than the Cartesian decomposition.

3.2 State Estimation for known network topologies

Generally the estimation of a network state is computed employing a weighted least square (WLS) method. Given a set of mğ‘šm measurements Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} with measurement errors ÏµA,isubscriptitalic-Ïµğ´ğ‘–\epsilon_{A,i} and a set of laws A0â€‹(ğ)subscriptğ´0ğA_{0}(\mathbf{B}) depending on the NBsubscriptğ‘ğµN_{B} network parameters Bjsubscriptğµğ‘—B_{j}, each measurement is expressed as

Ai=A0â€‹(ğ)+ÏµA,i.subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ´0ğsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ´ğ‘–A_{i}=A_{0}(\mathbf{B})+\epsilon_{A,i}\ . (3.10)

Assuming that the measurement errors ÏµA,isubscriptitalic-Ïµğ´ğ‘–\epsilon_{A,i} have null mean and a variance Ïƒi2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2\sigma_{i}^{2}, the standard WLS minimization method relies on the definition of a quadratic objective function Jâ€‹(ğ^)ğ½^ğJ(\mathbf{\hat{B}}) to be minimized with respect to the quantities to estimate B^jsubscript^ğµğ‘—\hat{B}_{j}

Jâ€‹(ğ^)=âˆ‘i=1m>N(Aiâˆ’A0,iâ€‹(ğ^))â€‹(Aiâˆ’A0,iâ€‹(ğ^))âˆ—Ïƒi2,ğ½^ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ´0ğ‘–^ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ´0ğ‘–^ğsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2J(\mathbf{\hat{B}})=\sum_{i=1}^{m>N}\frac{\left(A_{i}-A_{0,i}(\mathbf{\hat{B}})\right)\left(A_{i}-A_{0,i}(\mathbf{\hat{B}})\right)^{*}}{\sigma_{i}^{2}}\ , (3.11)

such that the solution of the system of NBsubscriptğ‘ğµN_{B} equations

dâ€‹Jdâ€‹B^j=0,j=1,â€¦,NB,formulae-sequenceğ‘‘ğ½ğ‘‘subscript^ğµğ‘—0ğ‘—1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğµ\frac{dJ}{d\hat{B}_{j}}=0\ ,\ j=1,\ldots,N_{B}\ , (3.12)

constitutes the state estimate obtained from the mğ‘šm measurements for a network with a state defined by NBsubscriptğ‘ğµN_{B} parameters. If any set of Ngsubscriptğ‘ğ‘”N_{g} constraints gkâ€‹(ğ)=0subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜ğ0g_{k}(\mathbf{B})=0 must be considered, these may be included in the quadratic objective function through the Lagrange multiplier method. In the following we are considering only simultaneously measurements of nodal injections Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i} and potentials Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}, when some delay between the actual measurements and the recording of its values exist it may be considered a synchronization which performs the measurement in advance of the network analysis accounting for such delay. Next we will test several definitions for the quadratic objective function and carry a statistical benchmark for the several network types discussed in the introduction. The most standard definition for this function is

We note that the specific expression for the weight Î£isubscriptÎ£ğ‘–\Sigma_{i} does influence the error of the estimates for the potentials and injections with respect to the actual values. We will carry a preliminary analysis for several possible definitions of this weight later on.

The minimization ofÂ (3.17) is performed with respect to the estimated quantities P^isubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–\hat{P}_{i} and to the injections for which measurements do not exist L~i=L^isubscript~ğ¿ğ‘–subscript^ğ¿ğ‘–\tilde{L}_{i}=\hat{L}_{i}. The most simple method to estimate the injections is to apply the lawÂ (3.4) to the estimated potentials

L^i=âˆ‘j=1NYiâ€‹jâ€‹P^j,subscript^ğ¿ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘—subscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘—\hat{L}_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}Y_{ij}\hat{P}_{j}\ , (3.18)

such that these estimates for the injections L^isubscript^ğ¿ğ‘–\hat{L}_{i} and the estimates for the potentials P^isubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–\hat{P}_{i} is obtained fromÂ (3.17) define de network state.

Alternatively it may be defined a quadratic objective function independent of the estimated values for the potentials P^isubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–\hat{P}_{i} computed fromÂ (3.17)

Hence, minimizing this function we obtain a distinct estimate for the injections L^isubscript^ğ¿ğ‘–\hat{L}_{i} which, together with the estimate for the potentials P^isubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–\hat{P}_{i} obtained fromÂ (3.17) defines the network state.

In addition the functionÂ (3.17) can be minimized for the nodal potentials P^isubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–\hat{P}_{i} simultaneously with the minimization, for the nodal injections L^isubscript^ğ¿ğ‘–\hat{L}_{i}, of the quadratic objective function

Next we carry a numerical statistical benchmark of the four distinct set of quadratic objective function for the several network types. In our analysis the exact values of the potentials and injections are P0,isubscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ‘–P_{0,i} and L0,isubscriptğ¿0ğ‘–L_{0,i} and the errors for the measurements Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} and Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i} are assumed to be given as a percentage Ïµ%subscriptitalic-Ïµpercent\epsilon_{\%} of the actual values for P0,isubscriptğ‘ƒ0ğ‘–P_{0,i} and L0,isubscriptğ¿0ğ‘–L_{0,i} with a statistical Gaussian distribution of null mean and standard deviation Ïƒ%subscriptğœpercent\sigma_{\%}

These standard deviations correspond either to the instrumentation accuracy, when known, or can be directly computed from measurement data assuming that the mean is null.

We note that the amount of improvement of the estimate errors with respect to the measurement error for all these estimate procedures does depend in several of the network parameters and topology as well as on the per unit reference quantities employed. Hence there is no unique choice for a better method or parameter scaling that can be universally applied to all existing power networks. For exemplification purposes, in the following we are carrying a benchmark analysis based on a set of randomly generated networks and measurement errors. For a known network, a dedicated benchmark must be carried allowing for a significant improvement of the estimate errors.

3.3 State Estimation in the presence of Gross Errors

For a given network, once the analysis on the previous section is performed such that a specific quadratic objective function and weight Î£isubscriptÎ£ğ‘–\Sigma_{i} are chosen, we can generally identify both gross measurement errors and network topological faults.

Typically, when a gross measurement error occurs at either a node potential or injection, the deviations from the Kirchoff laws become more significant at that node such that the difference between the measured quantities and estimated quantities become much larger than in the absence of gross measurement errors. Identifying such discrepancies allows to identify the measurements containing these errors and discard them when estimating the network state. We exemplify the occurrence and discarding of such gross measurement errors for the network represented in figureÂ 3.9 in figureÂ 3.10.

In addition we note that often, when a gross measurement error occurs at a given node, depending on the specific network topology, it may affect significantly the estimates for the quantities in adjacent nodes. This occurrence is also exemplified in figureÂ 3.10.

To detect the existence of such gross measurement errors it is enough to set a threshold for the quantities (Piâˆ’P^i)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–2(P_{i}-\hat{P}_{i})^{2} and (Liâˆ’L^i)2superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscript^ğ¿ğ‘–2(L_{i}-\hat{L}_{i})^{2} above which a correction procedure is trigged checking whether the value of the quadratic objective function is lower when the specific nodal measurements are discarded. If this is the case, the measurements are discarded. A refinement of this procedure may include the checking of the neighbors nodal measurements as well as next neighbors nodal measurements. Such refinement will make the detection procedure slower. We also note that it is required that the ration between a gross error and the standard white noise level be significant, otherwise these two sources of measurement error are not distinguishable.

3.4 State Estimation in the presence of topological faults

A topological fault constitutes an unaccounted opening or closing of a switch siâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜s_{ik} such that the respective branch iâ€‹kğ‘–ğ‘˜ik is erroneously represented in the matrix Ystatesubscriptğ‘ŒstateY_{\mathrm{state}} employed in the definition of the functions Jğ½J and state estimation. Hence, for a given set of potentials Pğ‘ƒP and injections Iğ¼I, mathematically the problem of topology estimation can be formulated as the integer NP-hard problem of estimating the quantities defining the switchers state s^iâ€‹ksubscript^ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜\hat{s}_{ik}

Specifically this problem can be solved by employing either heuristic algorithms (e.g. Simplex), discrete numerical methods (e.g. Gradient method) or enumeration.

When only a subset of the topology is unknown the problem is significantly simplified. In particular if a single switch state iâ€‹kğ‘–ğ‘˜ik is unknown we obtain that

For a given state estimation for the Pğ‘ƒPâ€™s and Lğ¿Lâ€™s, this result allows to identify whether the assumed topology is correctly estimated or not. When a wrong topology is assumed for the switcher iâ€‹kğ‘–ğ‘˜ik the quantities (Piâˆ’P^i)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘–2(P_{i}-\hat{P}_{i})^{2}, (Pkâˆ’P^k)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘˜2(P_{k}-\hat{P}_{k})^{2}, (Liâˆ’L^i)2superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscript^ğ¿ğ‘–2(L_{i}-\hat{L}_{i})^{2} and (Lkâˆ’L^k)2superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜subscript^ğ¿ğ‘˜2(L_{k}-\hat{L}_{k})^{2} are much bigger than the ones for the remaining nodes. Setting a threshold for these quantities generally allows to identify at least one of the nodes iğ‘–i or kğ‘˜k. Once a faulty node is identified, flipping the switchers connecting to the identified node and comparing the quadratic objective function for the alternative topologies obtained it is chosen the topology that minimizes the function Jğ½J being employed such that the assumed topology os corrected. This procedure requires only as many computations as the closest integer to pğ‘p (the network connectivity). For the network with topology represented in figureÂ 3.11 we exemplify these procedure for two simultaneously faults in figureÂ 3.12. Although correcting only one fault at a time it successfully corrects several faults successively.

3.5 Generic State Estimation

Let us now describe how to implement a procedure to fault detection and correction in a generic network with unknown topology and state. From the previous section we have concluded that we required:

  • â€¢

    to estimate the nodal potentials P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P} and injections L^^ğ¿\hat{L};

  • â€¢

    to estimate full topology, hence defining a network initial state;

  • â€¢

    to estimate the network topology evolution.

Hence to actually implement such a procedure we are considering two distinct steps which should run cyclically:

  • â€¢

    globally estimate full topology by an integer programming algorithm;

  • â€¢

    locally estimate and correct topological faults and gross errors as network evolves.

The first step is slow, however must be run periodically to reset the network to a known reliable state. The second stage is faster, however the faults are inspected locally, hence is not as reliable as the first step. We consider the following computational method:

  1. 1.

    estimate the potentials P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P} and injections L^^ğ¿\hat{L} by minimizing a given quadratic objective function Jğ½J chosen from the ones discussed previously;

  2. 2.

    estimate the full topology defining the initial state by solving the full integer NP-Hard problem, i.e. find a feasible solution for the set of linear constraints

    (YP^L^)âˆ’Ïµâ‰¤âˆ‘iâ€‹ksiâ€‹kziâ€‹kMiâ€‹kP^â‰¤(YP^L^)+Ïµ,siâ€‹kâˆˆ{0,1},(Y\hat{P}\hat{L})-\epsilon\leq\sum_{ik}\frac{s_{ik}}{z_{ik}}M_{ik}\hat{P}\leq(Y\hat{P}\hat{L})+\epsilon\ \ ,\ \ s_{ik}\in\{0,1\}\ , (3.35)

    where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is estimated from the errors for P^^ğ‘ƒ\hat{P} and L^^ğ¿\hat{L}.

  3. 3.

    estimate the network topology evolution by identifying and correcting the topology faults and gross errors:

    1. (a)

      set a noise level threshold Î´ğ›¿\delta for the potentials Î´Psubscriptğ›¿ğ‘ƒ\delta_{P}, injections Î´Lsubscriptğ›¿ğ¿\delta_{L} and optionally to the active power Î´aâ€‹psubscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘\delta_{ap} and/or reactive power Î´râ€‹psubscriptğ›¿ğ‘Ÿğ‘\delta_{rp};

    2. (b)

      detect the possibility of fault by defining at each node kğ‘˜k the forward and backward average of nğ‘›n measurements estimates <Pkâˆ’P^k>bsubscriptexpectationsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘<P_{k}-\hat{P}_{k}>_{b}, <Pkâˆ’P^k>fsubscriptexpectationsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘“<P_{k}-\hat{P}_{k}>_{f}, <Lkâˆ’L^k>bsubscriptexpectationsubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜subscript^ğ¿ğ‘˜ğ‘<L_{k}-\hat{L}_{k}>_{b}, <Lkâˆ’L^k>fsubscriptexpectationsubscriptğ¿ğ‘˜subscript^ğ¿ğ‘˜ğ‘“<L_{k}-\hat{L}_{k}>_{f}, <pâ€‹ak>bsubscriptexpectationğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘<pa_{k}>_{b}, <pâ€‹akâˆ’pâ€‹a^k>fsubscriptexpectationğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘“<pa_{k}-\hat{pa}_{k}>_{f}, <pâ€‹rkâˆ’pâ€‹r^k>bsubscriptexpectationğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘<pr_{k}-\hat{pr}_{k}>_{b} and <pâ€‹rkâˆ’pâ€‹r^k>fsubscriptexpectationğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘“<pr_{k}-\hat{pr}_{k}>_{f}, where the index bğ‘b stands for â€™backwardâ€™ and the index fğ‘“f stands for â€™forwardâ€™. We note that the evolution algorithm clearly distinguish the existence of gross errors from topological faults. When a gross error occurs the flipping of the switchers does not decrease the function Jğ½J.

The efficacy and efficiency of the several stages of this method significantly depends on the value of Ïƒ%subscriptğœpercent\sigma_{\%}. In figureÂ 3.13 it is plotted the rising of the percentage of switcher states wrongly estimated as a function of Ïƒ%subscriptğœpercent\sigma_{\%} when the global network state is estimated. InÂ 3.14 it is plotted the evolution of the percentage of switchers faults correctly corrected and the percentage of adjacent switchers analyzed. As it is readily verified only for relatively low Ïƒ%<0.01subscriptğœpercent0.01\sigma_{\%}<0.01 the method has a success of fault detection and correction over 99%percent9999\%.

3.6 Fault detectability

Given exact values for potentials P0subscriptğ‘ƒ0P_{0} and injections L0subscriptğ¿0L_{0} and two distinct topologies allowing for this network state Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1} and Y2subscriptğ‘Œ2Y_{2} we obtain the linear system:

{Y1â€‹P0=L0Y2â€‹P0=L0â‡”(Y1âˆ’Y2)â€‹P0=0.casessubscriptğ‘Œ1subscriptğ‘ƒ0subscriptğ¿0subscriptğ‘Œ2subscriptğ‘ƒ0subscriptğ¿0â‡”subscriptğ‘Œ1subscriptğ‘Œ2subscriptğ‘ƒ00\left\{\begin{array}[]{rcl}Y_{1}P_{0}&=&L_{0}\\[14.22636pt] Y_{2}P_{0}&=&L_{0}\end{array}\right.\ \ \Leftrightarrow\ \ (Y_{1}-Y_{2})P_{0}=0\ . (3.37)

Reversely, given two distinct topologies, these are mathematically indistinguishable for every exact value of P0subscriptğ‘ƒ0P_{0} which is a solution of these equations. The solutions to this system of equations correspond to the null space of the matrix Y1âˆ’Y2subscriptğ‘Œ1subscriptğ‘Œ2Y_{1}-Y_{2}. Considering the matrix basis Miâ€‹ksubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘˜M_{ik} it is straight forward to obtain the solution:

Miâ€‹kâ€‹P=0â‡”Pi=Pk,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘ƒ0â‡”subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜M_{ik}P=0\ \ \Leftrightarrow\ \ P_{i}=P_{k}\ , (3.38)

such that the topologies differing by the flip of the switch iâ€‹kğ‘–ğ‘˜ik with Pi=Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{i}=P_{k} are not distinguishable, although both topologies may be admissible in a real network. The example of two such topologies, differing only by the state of the switch 121212 is pictured in figureÂ 3.15.

However with measurement white noise

Pi+ÏµP,i=Pk+ÏµP,k.subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘ƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{i}+\epsilon_{P,i}=P_{k}+\epsilon_{P,k}\ . (3.39)

is a possible physical condition, hence measurements with a relatively small projection in the orthogonal space to the null space of the difference of admittance matrices corresponding to distinct topologies are mathematically indistinguishable.

We verify that this is the main cause for the undetectability of faults. Considering a statistical sample of several distinct topologies and measurement errors the faults which are not detectable, hence not corrected by the method described in the previous section, correspond to measurements for which the potentials vector is nearly parallel to the null space of the matrix Î”â€‹Y=Yeâ€‹xâ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹tâˆ’Ykâ€‹nâ€‹oâ€‹wâ€‹nÎ”ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘¤ğ‘›\Delta Y=Y_{exact}-Y_{known}, i.e. the change of topology due to the fault being detected. This result is plotted in figureÂ 3.16.

3.7 Conclusions and recommendations

Hence we have fully described an algorithm to estimate power network state. We have concluded that the main source of uncertainty is the existence of indistinguishable topologies. This is a well known problemÂ [3, 4] being also the main mechanism that allows for successful attacks in communication networksÂ [5].

The particular algorithm described here requires to fine-tune the quadratic objective function as well as the remaining parameters (weights, noise threshold, etc). For specific networks with an higher number of nodes it is required to redo the analysis and statistics carried in this report to optimize the detection and correction of topology and measurement errors. We further note that, when aiming at estimating the values of the power fluxes, instead of the nodal potentials and injections, it is required an explicit dependence of these quantities in the quadratic objective function. As possible detectability improvement it may be considered the checking of next-neighbors nodes and/or switchers, however the method is slower.
